reviewText:
[SUMMARY]

For a game that is free to play, and has very little download time it is most certainly worth your time, if you got 30 minutes or so spare, download this game and play it. Do note if you are under the age of 13, that you need to think carefully before playing this game, because it might scare younger players, but to be honest do feel free to play it, and finish it. Totally recommend: 8/10.

[IN DEPTH REVIEW]

So, you still have your doubts huh? Well, I’ll explain why it is so great.

The storyline is so brilliant for an indie horror game, to be honest I hate horror games, but this, was something I actually enjoyed, it has no jump scares (although I did rush the game for the review, I may update it later if there is one, that I may have missed during rushing), and is purely driven about the idea of psychological horror, and that’s what makes it such a compelling storyline, and, despite the multiple chills I felt going down my back, I continued, because I wanted to see what would happen, and how it would end.

In terms of playability, it is, like most indie games, a pick up and play, the only thing that will make you think, is the complexity of the situation, and not which controls you need to press, the themes of this game is mildly concerning, (not going to spoil anything) and at the end, really makes you think about yourself, and if what your doing is right. I really struggled to get started on this review, purely because it keep returning to my mind, but, that is what the game is meant to do to you.

The game itself is quite a lot more serious than the clone of games being released every 3 weeks (*cough* Five Nights at Freddy’s *cough*), and is a ton better than whatever they are releasing, so before spending some of your hard earned cash, (or not so hard earned cash, I don’t know how you get money), why not give this a whirl first? Truth to be told, it has more entertainment value than You-Know-What.

My only complaint about the game would be that the game really could and should have been a great deal longer, the story and plot line has so much room for expansion, don’t get me wrong this game is good as it is, but an update or something to have more of a capitalisation upon the story of the characters (trying not to spoil here), as it was not really explained enough to really give to effective of a cliff-hanger, but is suppose, it is about the psychological effects more than the plot after all.

Addressing re-playability,  it looks the game that you might feel inclined to play and then play again immediately, or after a few weeks of intervals, because the story immerses you so well, (like I said room for expansion) that you really want to replay it, (after this review I’m probably going off to replay it, because it’s so good), but, to be honest, it doesn’t need to be replayed, however, if you got the time, replay it, because it’s like your looking through a completely different perspective, and maybe I would of get FNAF 2 if I had the ability to be the animatronics, but to be honest, it isn’t up my street anyway, (I hate jump scares, poorest way of adding tension, but I’m not a game developer, so what do I know?), but I’m getting off topic.

Next on my list is the graphics, and when I say what you expected from a game that takes barely any time to download, your answer would probably be not much, however, this graphics, enhances the game, and makes it more immersive, it feels older, making you feel it is more unknown the games you normally play, and considering the engine used was Unity free version, you can count me impressed. I think the creator could not be more right with this “It features a unique artstyle that combines elements of pixel horror with realistic lighting effect, which is intended to enhance the surreal atmosphere”. That right there is exactly what it does, the graphic make it feel more real, it makes the atmosphere feel as if it is happening with just you in control of the body, and that the body you control, is you, and you want to know who is this character, and what is he/she doing here? What relevance does it have to the story? How does the title fit in with all this? And that is exactly why you play this game past the opening moments, because you want to know the answer, and you are going to play through this game multiple times just to find out what is going on here. And that is the true beauty of an indie game like this.

Last, but most certainly not least, the music. This tune, fits too well for this game, the eerie sound of the tune fits in perfectly with the game itself, as if the music was made specifically for the game (maybe it was?) because it naturally makes sense for the sounds being played and the game itself, I can’t have any real complaints about this game, because, on all aspects, its indie developer’s dream, because it doesn’t appear to have any bugs, its well-made and fluid.

I really want to say how impressed I am by this, and I give kudos to the creator for such a unique and enjoyable game, that has changed my opinion on all horror games, and the genre itself, maybe I might get those games with lots of zombies and jump scares in it… No. This game is beautifully original, and is hand crafted to a perfect game, and is an absolute gem.

If you’re still not willing to give this game a go, then… I don’t know, maybe you just don’t like psychological horror, or maybe you’re on your phone or something, and you can’t download it yet, who knows, maybe you’re holidaying in Belarus, and won’t be back for a while.

So, in a nutshell, good game, well played. Sorry for any mistakes, I’m not fluent English, if you have any questions, or want me to review a game, add me or drop a comment on this, or my profile.
And on that bombshell…

Goodnight!

P.S: I do know this game has been out since March last year, but just wasn’t on Steam

reviewText:
Fingerbones is the first horror game by David Szymanski, the creative mind that brought us such gems as The Moon Sliver and The Music Machine. Originally published in 2013, the game wound up on Steam around a year later. This title is a short exploratory horror mixed with narration in the way of journal pages scattered about. It's up to you to unravel the dark story within, by solving a simple series of puzzles.

I would be lying if I said that Fingerbones didn't keep me looking over my in-game shoulder, amidst the eerie crying of a child and dense fog. I was almost certain that I would see some demon-spawn in kid form awaiting me around the next corner, or behind a door. Needless to say, the thick and immersive atmosphere, however simplistic it may be, really sucks you in during the short timeframe of this narrative story. From the stand-alone mechanical howling of the generator in a well lit top level, to the forlorn cries of a child and creepy silence of the basement, every moment is suspenseful in some way.

The game uses Minecraft-like textures, in that everything is heavily and purposefully pixelated. Usually this distracts from any horror element that a game may have, turning them into child friendly PG-13 types. Thankfully, that is not the case here; however brief it may be, the chilling story is enough to send a shiver down the spine of any adult. The game only lasts 15-30 minutes at best, and there are only a handful of journal pages scattered about; it would've been nice if there was more story to this narrative-centric experience.

For a short and free horror title, Fingerbones is one of the best that you'll come across. Prepare to white-knuckle your mouse for the next half hour of entertainment, while anxiously waiting for what may be around the next bend. Take your time, don't rush, and read the pages carefully to fully understand what unimaginable horrors that this poor excuse of a father put his child through. Then, if you enjoyed yourself, go ahead and take a look at the other games from this fantastic developer.

reviewText:
Fingerbones is the next title from the same developer as The Moon Sliver, but will you want to play this ?

In Fingerbones we play as a man that walks around a basement and tries to relive past memories ( I will not go into further detail for the plot because that would spoil the entire game).

Gameplay is simple. All you do is walk around and pick up notes and solve a couple of puzzles. It's really simple stuff, but if you do play the game it will be for the story.

Graphics are simple pixel horror style, but use different lighting effects which gives the game a really awesome look.  Now some of the item models look a bit weird it's still a really good looking game.

Audio is fantastic. The audio will make you feel like you're not alone and it's just really well done. The music is really good to, but there's not much of it.

The game has really simple level design so I doubt anyone would get stuck in this game. There's not much more to say about it.

The game is really short. It took me 15 minutes to finish the entire thing and I loved every second of it. Apart from the one playthrough you will do there's not much replay value.

I didn't encounter any bugs what so ever. The game ran smoothly and I highly doubt that anyone would have problems playing it.

Overall Fingerbones is a really good indie horror game. Now I wouldn't say it's better than Moon Sliver, but it's still really good. I highly suggest playing through it at least once. I give Fingerbones a 8/10

reviewText:
Beautiful...Just beautiful.


This is exactly the type of videogame i have been looking for since 2012, after the release of the FANTASTIC psychological shooter Spec Ops : The Line.


Fingerbones is a different type of horror game. It isn't a horror game that uses cheap jumpscares to frighten you
Instead, Fingerbones uses your mind through different notes scattered around an environment that you need to read to uncover the secrets of the place you're in. At the beggining, you don't know who you are, where you are or what your purpose is. After reading every single note, uncovering every secret of this AMAZING but at the same time HORRIFIC
story, you finally find out who you are and what your purpose was from the beggining.


The game's main enemy is found right at the end, and this enemy will surprise you the same way as it surprised me.


The horrific story of the game somehow resembles I Am Legend combined with a Friday the 13th movie, although it's very original and the core is just a very tiny bit alike these 2 masterpieces.


Fingerbones can be finished in about 20-30 minutes, and uses no savegames.

Overall, all i can say is congratulations to the developer for creating this masterpiece. We need more games like these, games that make us think and eventually ♥♥♥♥ with our minds in both a good and a clever way.

I definitely recommend this game, and it definitely made it into my Gaming Hall of Fame

I rate it 10/10

reviewText:
A nice little thriller/psychological horror game that focuses on the core value of horror - the atmosphere.

During the game, nothing too significant happens but the way it builds up tension and suspense is quite remarkable. I also liked the way the puzzles link with the story of the game and the graphics (they're actually really well suited to the style of the game!).

The ending was also good with a small twist to it. Some of the sounds gave me a slight shiver too which I think ties in with the fantastic atmosphere this game has to offer.

If you're looking for something long winded and jumpscarish, don't waste your time with this game. However, if you're a fan of indie games, horror, and not things screaming in the face of the player, I really would recommend it!

9/10

Fingerbones is a free to play Walking Simulator about a scientist faced with the end of humanity as he knows it. I decided to play this game because i am a writer and thought i might try getting into more horror games for the sake of one of my current writing projects (which is horror-based). Fingerbones, i'm happy to say didn't dissapoint.

While the game is short and probably meant to be completed in 10 minutes or so, i spent an hour eating up the scenery. While basic and somewhat reminicent of Minecraft, the graphics formed a very good atmosphere. It's dark and mysterious and somewhat run down. The lighting in the rooms was also brilliant. The sunset you see as soon as you start the game up is GORGEOUS and i haven't seen many horror games that greet you with something as simple yet beautiful as a sunset. So that was a nice change... The gameplay over all is pretty mucha  walking simulator (or in this case, a back-tracking simulator) as you'll be going back and fourth to a small computer (well, technically just a keyboard) to type in code words to advance in the game. And by advance, i mean more just going into other rooms... Granted, as a writer i understand why some games are made and this developer was trying their hand at creating a narrative driven game, which i totally don't mind. I love games with story. For a first attempt at a narrative-driven game i wasn't really dissapointed. From a writer's perspective i noticed some flubs here and there but there is a lot worse fiction out there and the writing here fit the atmoshpere. The game itself also has a few tropes associtated with a first attempt to have a narrative-driven game (such as only using notes or text to convey the story, waking up in a mysterious abandoned location, ect), but i didn't mind that much because it was the dev's first try and I came for the horror elements of the story.

The character the player takes on is a scientist who has witnessed what he believes is the end of humanity and he has woken up in a bunker and through scattered notes do we the player find out more about the story. The notes are all we get in terms of story so they're all we have to go on to get an idea of the setting and the character we're playing as. Through the notes we find out he has a daughter who he had custody of when everything came crashing down and i won't spoil what happens from there... This character we play as is interesting, from both a scientific and writing perspective, it's not a character we see very often. He is deeply involved in science and is devoted to his work, he can admit that maybe having a child wasn't the best decision in his life and seems geuniely unsure of how to take care of his daughter during this disaster. We usually see a character like this as a villian rather than a main character, so that's a nice change. We're delving into the thought process and mental state of someone who only knows of science and can't really think outside of that structure.

Overall, this game is supposed to be surreal horror in it's narative. Honestly, i like it :) It's my kind of horror, like something you'd see in a foreign horror film. American horror films try to scare you with an antagonist or a monster, but foreign horror films (like ones from Asia) try to get you invested in the atmosphere and the goal isn't always trying to scare you, but more to get you into the story and narrative. The game (as short as it is) kept me thinking the whole way through and though it's not scary in the typical sence (you won't be seeing any Five Nights at Freddy's style jumpscares here), it got me to care and feel somewhat afraid for this scientist and his daughter. It was more the atmosphere that scared you, the sound of a girl crying in the distance, the ambient humming of a generator and a beep from a keyboard, finding the titular fingerbones hidden away...

As a lover of games with story, the only bad thing i have to say about the game is that it does become more of a back-tracking simulator very fast. You're constantly going back to the keyboard on the first floor to type in code words to advance and go to different locations. But the game was always intended to be about narrative and completed in one sitting, so i could easily let this slide.

In conclusion this was a short little narrative driven horror game which was FREE to play. I'm happy to say i really like it despite some of it's flaws and i'd be happy to see a fuller version of the story (maybe with a bigger map to play with). Good job dev, i give Fingerbones 4 fingerbones out of 5! AND THANK YOU FOR MAKING IT FREE!

The game was genuinely creepy and I'd dare say disturbing, it achieved actual psychological horror using the medium of video games in a way that no other game does it quite right.  You're apprehensive, you can hear something that sounds like a ghoul or a wraith, otherworldly.  It shocks your senses in the right way, and it never betrays you with a cheap RAHHH jump scare, it keeps you on the edge of your seat wondering if and when something terrible might happen.

Something terrible does happen, but it's based on really good use of video game mechanics, and not on crappy fluff where you get assaulted with Alma from F.E.A.R. or Kayako Saeki from The Grudge.  Instead, this game will freak you out in the right ways.  The only thing I might criticize is that the game's writing is a little too revealing at the beginning.  The game could pull back from a few of the plot reveals so early on (as I was able to easily see what was hiding), but I suppose at the same time, it leaves you with the apprehension of what's to come, so maybe it's not such a bad thing.

In the end the monster is revealed, but if you hadn't spotted it already, you'll wonder why you hadn't.

reviewText:
This game is quite peculiar, and one that make me wish there is a 'maybe' bottom.

The gameplay is practically non existent, but this is not necessary a bad thing, since the purpose of Fingerbones is to tell a story.

Ambients are... well, there are practically just three rooms in this game, so there isn't much to say.
On the other side, these few rooms make you feel really uneasy.

But let's focus on the plot, which is the true center of this game:


First of all, the themes of Fingerbones are not easy. I don't want to spoiler anything, but if you are a very sensible person, maybe this is not the game for you.
And I don't mean there are gory or terrifying jumpscares, but the story itself can be very disturbing.
The horror element is build only on the psychological level, and the only 'true' scares in Fingerbones are some sounds.

This kind of horror build-up is what I truly like in Fingerbones, since there are very few games that have managed to do that so well.
The anxiety is created as you read the notes and discover the terrible story of the protagonist and the place where you are, and the horror (or disgust) as you realize what has appened.

But, in my opinion, this is also the main flaw of this game: the focus on the story make it a bit sterile.
There is the story, and nothing else, and the plot itself is not completely explored as it deserves.

In the end, Fingerbones is not a bad game, and in many ways it succeeded where others have failed, but, it leaves the feeling that there is something missing, and the story could have been explained and expanded better

Fingerbones is a free to play Walking Simulator about a scientist faced with the end of humanity as he knows it. I decided to play this game because i am a writer and thought i might try getting into more horror games for the sake of one of my current writing projects (which is horror-based). Fingerbones, i'm happy to say didn't dissapoint.

While the game is short and probably meant to be completed in 10 minutes or so, i spent an hour eating up the scenery. While basic and somewhat reminicent of Minecraft, the graphics formed a very good atmosphere. It's dark and mysterious and somewhat run down. The lighting in the rooms was also brilliant. The sunset you see as soon as you start the game up is GORGEOUS and i haven't seen many horror games that greet you with something as simple yet beautiful as a sunset. So that was a nice change... The gameplay over all is pretty mucha  walking simulator (or in this case, a back-tracking simulator) as you'll be going back and fourth to a small computer (well, technically just a keyboard) to type in code words to advance in the game. And by advance, i mean more just going into other rooms... Granted, as a writer i understand why some games are made and this developer was trying their hand at creating a narrative driven game, which i totally don't mind. I love games with story. For a first attempt at a narrative-driven game i wasn't really dissapointed. From a writer's perspective i noticed some flubs here and there but there is a lot worse fiction out there and the writing here fit the atmoshpere. The game itself also has a few tropes associtated with a first attempt to have a narrative-driven game (such as only using notes or text to convey the story, waking up in a mysterious abandoned location, ect), but i didn't mind that much because it was the dev's first try and I came for the horror elements of the story.

The character the player takes on is a scientist who has witnessed what he believes is the end of humanity and he has woken up in a bunker and through scattered notes do we the player find out more about the story. The notes are all we get in terms of story so they're all we have to go on to get an idea of the setting and the character we're playing as. Through the notes we find out he has a daughter who he had custody of when everything came crashing down and i won't spoil what happens from there... This character we play as is interesting, from both a scientific and writing perspective, it's not a character we see very often. He is deeply involved in science and is devoted to his work, he can admit that maybe having a child wasn't the best decision in his life and seems geuniely unsure of how to take care of his daughter during this disaster. We usually see a character like this as a villian rather than a main character, so that's a nice change. We're delving into the thought process and mental state of someone who only knows of science and can't really think outside of that structure.

Overall, this game is supposed to be surreal horror in it's narative. Honestly, i like it :) It's my kind of horror, like something you'd see in a foreign horror film. American horror films try to scare you with an antagonist or a monster, but foreign horror films (like ones from Asia) try to get you invested in the atmosphere and the goal isn't always trying to scare you, but more to get you into the story and narrative. The game (as short as it is) kept me thinking the whole way through and though it's not scary in the typical sence (you won't be seeing any Five Nights at Freddy's style jumpscares here), it got me to care and feel somewhat afraid for this scientist and his daughter. It was more the atmosphere that scared you, the sound of a girl crying in the distance, the ambient humming of a generator and a beep from a keyboard, finding the titular fingerbones hidden away...

As a lover of games with story, the only bad thing i have to say about the game is that it does become more of a back-tracking simulator very fast. You're constantly going back to the keyboard on the first floor to type in code words to advance and go to different locations. But the game was always intended to be about narrative and completed in one sitting, so i could easily let this slide.

In conclusion this was a short little narrative driven horror game which was FREE to play. I'm happy to say i really like it despite some of it's flaws and i'd be happy to see a fuller version of the story (maybe with a bigger map to play with). Good job dev, i give Fingerbones 4 fingerbones out of 5! AND THANK YOU FOR MAKING IT FREE!
